Handshakes.Handshake: No security
Anonymous DH key-exchange is vulnerable to MITM.
Anonymous ECDH key-exchange is vulnerable to MITM.
Ephemeral DH key-exchange enforces perfect forward secrecy for long-term security.
Ephemeral DH key-exchange enforces perfect forward secrecy for long-term security.
The export variant of RSA is intentionally weak. see http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4346#appendix-A.5
The export variant of anonymous DH is intentionally weak. see http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4346#appendix-A.5
The export variant of DH-DSS is intentionally weak. see http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4346#appendix-A.5
The export variant of DH-RSA is intentionally weak. see http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4346#appendix-A.5
Diffie Hellman key exchange + Digital Signature Scheme authentication
Diffie Hellman key exchange + RSA authentication
Elliptic curve DH. EC constants maybe manipulated. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_EC_DRBG
Elliptic curve DH. EC constants maybe manipulated. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_EC_DRBG
Ephemeral ECDH key-exchange enforces perfect forward secrecy for long-term security. EC constants maybe manipulated. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_EC_DRBG
Ephemeral ECDH key-exchange enforces perfect forward secrecy for long-term security. EC constants maybe manipulated. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_EC_DRBG
Pre-shared keys are secure if they are large, random and regularly changed. See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4492
RSA is considered as the standard.
Secure Remote Password provides client authentication. See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2945
Secure Remote Password provides client authentication. See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2945
Secure Remote Password provides client authentication. See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2945

BulkCiphers.BulkCipher: AES with 128bits is considered as the standard.
AES with 128bits is considered as the standard.
AES with 128bits is considered as the standard.
AES with 128bits is considered as the standard.
AES with 256 bits provide long-term security.
Camellia is probably better than AES but not so extensively investigated, therefore rated as equal as AES. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camellia_%28cipher%29
Camellia is probably better than AES but not so extensively investigated, therefore rated as equal as AES. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camellia_%28cipher%29
3DES is still secure but slow. See http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/26179/security-comparsion-of-3des-and-aes
3DES is still secure but slow. See http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/26179/security-comparsion-of-3des-and-aes
SEED has no known vulnerabilities, but is not well studied. http://crypto.stackexchange.com/questions/11404/cryptanalysis-and-weaknesses-of-seed-cipher

Hashes.Hash: No signature is the worst option
